Name: UCSD-opoly
Description: This is a University of California at San Diego themed variant of Monopoly.  Houses and Hotels are replaced by Years of Credit and Diplomas.  There are no auctions, and all money required to be paid other than rent and the purchase price of properties is placed in the center of the board.  Any player landing on Spring Break (Free Parking) collects all of the money from the center of the board. Playing pieces are History, Art, Anatomy, English, and Calculus textbooks.  Unique properties include the Quonset Huts, the Price Center,  the Guardian, the Sun God, the Koala, Revelle Plaza Fountain, the Hump,   Genesee Avenue, Che' Cafe, Canyon View Pool, Muir College, Warren College, Fifth College, Revelle College, and Thurgood Marshall College.

Name: Legends of the Ancient World: Wolves on the Rhine
Description:
In a lonely outpost, on the border between the Roman Empire and the barbarian hinterlands stands a small group of Roman soldiers.  Raids by barbarian hordes threaten your Legion, and soon the Empire itself!  Someone is growing rich from these raids and it may not be the barbarians alone.  As the Twentieth Legion teeters on the brink of collapse, YOU must find a way to stop the Wolves on the Rhine!

Wolves on the Rhine is a complete historical fiction adventure for solitaire or group play.  This game includes the adventure booklet, game rules, playing pieces and game board.  It is suitable for ages 12 and up and can be played with either the included Legends of the Ancient World games system or other game systems such as Melee.

Home Page: http://www.darkcitygames.com/display.php?series=law&id=10
Families: Series: Legends of the Ancient World (Dark City Games)

Description:
Rules for English Civil War wargames with army lists and campaign system.

This set of rules was developed from the author's house rules, originally designed for the War of Spanish Succession, and subsequently adapted for a wide variety of periods.

Name: Mare Nostrum
Description:
Mare Nostrum is a expansion for AmirautÃ©. It contains tactical and strategic scenarios for the Mediterranean war in 1940-1943, and new rules. It contains also ship cards for French, Italian, and British navies.

Expands:

    AmirautÃ©

Name: Forlorn Hope
Description: Miniatures wargames rules for the English Civil War.  Recently revised and expanded by Partizan Press.  Contains army lists for King, Parliament and the Covenant forces plus Catholic and Protestant Irish; color plates depicting numerous flags from all of the factions, with particular attention to the London Trained Bands and 4 introductory scenarios, in colour, explore the many varied engagements of the period (Tadcaster 1642, Corbridge 1644, Dunbar 1650, Wigan Lane 1651).

Name: Black Pawn Trucking
Description:
As the owner of a small freight operation, you must travel around the U.K carrying raw goods and finished products to their destinations.

This is a solitaire game for the piecepack system where the aim is to stay solvent for one game year, and if possible make  a profit. Plan your routes and where to bring each good carefully, and don't take too many loans, or it could mean the end of your business.

Name: Happily Ever After Card Game
Description:
Help Ariel kiss her Prince before sunset so she can become human and live happily ever after.

Collect one Ariel, one Prince Eric, one Kiss, and one Princess Ariel card of the same color to win!  Be the first Princess to help Ariel live happily ever after!

Ages 4 and up
Families: Folk Tales & Fairy Tales: The Little Mermaid

Name: Memorise
Description:
To score points by memorizing details from and answering questions about a passage of text.

Players, either individually or in teams are invited into the world of some of the greatest storytellers ever. Short extracts from famous and classic novels take you into their world of thrills, chills, comedy and romance - but can you memorize what you have read?

If you can, and can answer your questions correctly, you'll score points. From simple "either/or" questions to real tests of memory and recall.  Memorise is an exciting and tense battle of wit and nerve.  Tactics and strategy may allow you to secure valuable bonus points.

This game is simple to learn and, unlike most question and answer games, requires no previous knowledge.  All the answers are in the passage that you have just read - but can you memorise them?.

This game also gives you a flavor of the contents of a number of famous and classic novels.

Note: Memorise appears to be a reprint of Echelon. The text and question cards are exactly the same, but a cheaper board and playing pieces have been substituted.

Name: Maxwell: The Game
Description:
A rather tongue-in-cheek game of amusement at the expense of Robert Maxwell!

The purpose is to become a tycoon and then become the administrator for the pension fund!

The aim is to land on the Maxwell Squares and collect the 5 different items that enable you to become a tycoon:  Newspaper Owner, Yacht owner, Football Club director, Cigar smoker, and finally Pension Fund Administrator.

To win the game, you must have collected all 5 cards, and then be the first person to the pension fund. To do this you must first accept that you have died!!!  You must then move along the 3 sets of coins before entering your kingdom of untold riches. The first to the riches wins.

Name: Matchday
Description: As Team Manager, the player's goal is to lead his football (soccer) team to win the League Championship during the course of one season's play. Game uses some ideas from Monopoly, but also features the matches, injuries, transfers, gate attendance, and other aspects of being a football manager.

Name: Match and Move
Description: Each player must try to move his four pieces across the board to the opposite side.  The winner is the first player to do so.  There is no "taking" or removing shapes from the board, and there must never be more than one piece on any square. Players have to match shape or color to move.

Name: Marenko: The Phrase Game
Description:
To accumulate the highest amount of Marenko Points by composing meaningful and correct sentences with the available cards.

520 special cards to compose sentences, together with 72 x sold vinyl "chips". Everybody rewards you whenever you form a good sentence. You also get rewards any time you expand somebody else's phrase.

Name: Maindealer
Description:
A very unusual and interesting adaptation of real life car sales/trading translated into a boardgame.

You start play as a normal everyday person, a "punter", whose compelling ambition is to become a car dealer. Through life's ups and downs, you must collect the 5 cars you need, of any make, to become a garage owner.

Once a garage owner, you move to the next level on the board, with the opportunity to buy & sell additional cars, and also to aim for a main dealership - if you have sufficient stock of one make of car.

A very clever and absorbing game- easy to pick up as you go.

Name: Monopoly: German
Description:
Released in the 1930's in Germany by licensee Firma Franz Schmidt.

Gameplay is the same as the original Monopoly.  The Currency is the German deutschmark.

The release is notable for having a board that folds into quarters, rather than halves.

- Go is Los
- Chance and Community Chest are Ereignis-fach and Gemeinschafts-fach, respectively
- Trafalgar Square is Opernplatz
- Boardwalk is SchloBallee

Name: Château: Vinspelet
Description:
Each player starts the game in charge of a small wine trading company with contacts to wineries in three different countries. Your company is represented on the board by a wine merchant and a buyer. These pawns move around the board in hope of buying fine wines and their requisite grapes. A wine and grape combination together form an agency.
The game ends when one player has at least six agencies representing at least five different countries. But the winner is the one with the most successful company, i.e. the highest monetary value of combined resources.

Name: Pop-Cones
Description: This is like a junior version of "Trouble" and features Kohner's trademark Pop-O-Matic.  Tokens are cones as you'd see in Kohner's "Headache" game.  Same object as any of those go-around-the-board-to-Home games.

Name: Photo-opoly
Description:
No one takes a picture of something they want to forget! Make a game that is unforgettable! Where are your photos anyway? Photo albums? Stored on the memory card of your digital camera? Stuffed in shoe boxes under the bed?

CALLING ALL PHOTOS! COME OUT AND PLAY! Choose 22 favorite photos and create a game for: A BIRTHDAY, A FAMILY REUNION, A WEDDING, A PARTY, A BABY SHOWER, AN ANNIVERSARY, ANY CELEBRATION, ANY EVENT. You don’t even really need an occasion!

Maybe you’ve just always wanted to make your own game! Materials and instructions included for creating your game in many different ways.

Name: Fishin'-opoly
Description:
from the publishers:

THE GAME THAT WILL REEL YOU IN, HOOK, LINE AND SINKER!
Gone Fishin’ – when grouped together, two of the most beautiful words in the English language! Fishin’-opoly allows players to buy, sell and trade their favorite fish and gear with family and friends. Players choose their tokens and advance to Cast. It’s all fun and games until someone lands on SNAG, gets all hung up, and is out of the game for three turns! While playing, flip over the deeds and learn some fun fishin’ facts. And you know what they say, “A bad day of fishin’ is still better than a good day at work!”

Name: Farm-opoly
Description:
from the publishers:

Here's a property tradin' game for farmers or those who just think farmin' is cool! It's life down on the farm where players increase their profit by collecting Acres and trading them in for Big Red Barns.  Full of country humor and fun farm facts, Farm-opoly is a celebration of an All-American way of life!

Name: DIY-opoly
Description:
from the publishers:

A DO IT YOURSELF PROPERTY TRADING GAME!
Is your idea of high fashion a well-equipped tool belt?
Is your ideal vacation one in which you remodel the kitchen?
Do you spend your night out at the local hardware store?

If you answered yes to any or all of the above, D.I.Y.OPOLY is the game for you. Even you need a little R & R every now and then! Gather family and friends and welcome them into your world of power tools, elbow grease, and sawdust.

In D.I.Y.- OPOLY players buy, sell and trade favorite properties, then increase the property value by adding Tool Buckets and Hardware Stores. It sounds easy enough, but add a trip to the emergency room, a project you can’t handle, and an exploding toilet, and it gets a little more difficult, and a lot more fun! So choose your token and advance to “Get to Work!” Who knows? You may soon be elected Handyman of the Year…or you may get in over your head and have to hire a contractor. Whatever happens, it’s gonna be almost as fun as building a deck!

Name: Bookopoly
Description:
from the publishers:

OPEN A BOOK! THE WORLD AWAITS YOU!

Book-opoly allows players a glimpse inside the many worlds of classic literature. It’s a traditional property trading game where players buy, sell and trade their way to fun with family and friends. Interesting facts about the books and the authors are printed on the back of each property deed. Roll the dice and advance to Read. Collect Bookstores and trade them in for Libraries. Who knows! You may soon be elected President of the Book Club…or you may be tossed out of the game for three turns and sent to WATCH TV!

Name: Rodeo-opoly
Description:
from the publishers:

Giddy up Cowboys and Cowgirls! Here’s a game celebratin’ the rodeo! Whether you enjoy rodeo from the back of a bull, the saddle of a bronc, or viewed on the wide screen in the comfort of your easy chair, you’ll have a whole mess a’ fun playin’ Rodeo-opoly with family and friends! Full of rodeo humor and rodeo facts, Rodeo-opoly is a big “Hats Off” to this fascinatin’ sport and way of life.  Buy favorite rodeo properties. Increase rent on your properties by collecting Scores and trading them in for Gold Buckles. It’s all fun and games until you’re sent to Bucked Off, then you’re skiddin’ on your back side across the board and you’re out for three turns!

Name: Maatilapeli
Description:
Players are part-time farmers in Maatilapeli. Each player owns a small farm with some arable land and forest. It is possible to grow wheat, potatoes, sugar beets and strawberries. Players buy seeds, sow and harvest them and sell the crop paying also taxes. The most successful farmer in terms of capital wins.

A round of the square game board represents one year, each side roughly representing one season: in winter players decide which seeds to buy and to what extent, in spring the seeds are sown, in summer (and partly autumn) it is the harvest time.

Advancing on the board happens by rolling a die. Each square represents one week and has special instructions on it: paying random expenses, drawing a surprise card, getting income out of the forest etc.

The harvest times of different plants are sequential and differ in length. The die roll the player lands on one of the harvest squares of certain plant also determines the hectare price of that crop (lookup table used). It is possible to miss the harvest season of any plant resulting in a crop failure for which the state pays a small compensation.

Harvesting machinery may be bought to increase the crop price and a tractor decreases the sowing expenses. More land can be rented or bought as well. At the end of the year the taxes are paid, the accounts balanced and a new year may begin.

The game includes two sets of rules: in the simplified set e.g. everyone grows one hectare of each plant, there is no machinery or, obviously, no option to rent or buy more land.

Name: Bug-opoly
Description:
from the publishers:

A CREEPING, CRAWLING, PROPERTY TRADING GAME!

Bug-opoly is a look inside the wonderful bug kingdom. Buy, sell and trade your favorite insects (and a few of their friends because not every bug included in the game is technically an insect.) As you play, flip over the deeds and read some amazing and fun facts. Gather family and friends and get buggy with it! Who knows? You may soon be elected president of the Entomological Society…or you may be sent to Bug Off, and out of the game for three turns! Whatever happens, the game will be crawling with good fun!

Name: Splurge
Description: Splurge is an exciting game of skill and fortune for 2 to 6 players.  It incorporates in a single board game a number of famous and popular dice and card games (poker, blackjack, craps, etc...).  Each player attempts to win by a combination of plays on the board and successful side-betting with other players in the game.  The game is ended when one player gets both his tokens to the finish, and the winner is the player who has accumulated the most money at that time.

Name: Task Force 421 (Iran-Iraq naval war, 1980)
Description:
Task Force 421 is an attempted simulation of the most important combined naval and air battle of the Iran-Iraq War 1980-1988, named Operation Morvarid (pearl), in a tactical/operational level. This particular battle took place in two days, during 27 and 28 November 1980; initiated by Iran landing a small Special Forces demolition team aboard the Iraqi al-Bakr offshore platform. Al-Bakr was a significant intelligence gathering post, and a safe haven for the Iraqi missile boats, from which to operate against the Iranian shipping. Before the start of the war, over one-third of the Iraq’s oil was exported via al-Bakr and the nearby al-Omayeh platform.

The main map illustrates the northern Persian Gulf and parts of the Iranian, Iraqi and Kuwaiti coasts, divided into flat-up hexes, each representing a distance of 4.5 kilometers across.

A unit is an individual naval vessel or aircraft. The counters represent the Iranian and Iraqi naval and air forces, distinguishable by color, and their national flags. The Iraqi counters have beige background, while the Iranian counters have grey background.
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players

Name: Dien Bien Phu: Trenches in the Tropics
Description: Dien Bien Phu: Trenches in the Tropics is a simple simulation of the battle of Dien Bien Phu (March 13 – May 7 1954). This decisive battle saw French elite troops (paratroopers of Bigeard and the Légion étrangère) defeated by the Vietminh led by General Vo Nguyen Giap. It put an end to the French domination over Indochina and was a great victory for the Vietnamese Communist party who would be seen, after this event, as the party who gave freedom to its own people. Dien Bien Phu: Trenches in the Tropics is a two-player war game. One player commands the Vietminh, while the other commands the French forces.

Name: Say Cheese
Description:
Grab the entire card deck, Say Cheese and win!

Based on the War card game. Your goal is take all the cheese cards by drawing higher numbered cards than your opponent. In the event of tie, extra cards are drawn and compared to determine who wins the playoff. But keep an eye out for the cat and mouse trap cards as they can help you get additional bonus cards.

Name: Juneau-Opoly
Description: Juneau-Opoly was designed in 2006 as a fund-raising board game for the Juneau Douglas High School Band Program.  It is played much like Monopoly in that players roll dice to advance around the board and purchase properties.  Properties are named after Juneau, AK businesses and once a player acquires all the businesses in a set he/she may purchase customers to make the business  collect more when other players land on them.  There are also fate and foxfire spaces that force the player to draw a random event card when landed on.  These cards have a variety of effects, such as giving or taking away money.  The game is won when a player manages to bankrupt everyone else.  A player becomes bankrupt when he lands on an owned property that he/she can't pay the owner for.

Name: Operation Husky (1943)
Description:
“OPERATION HUSKY” (10 July – 17 August 1943)

American, British and Canadian troops land in the South of the Island. Their aim is to reach Messina, as the final plan is to liberate Italy from the German occupation. It is likely that the Axis would begin to evacuate forces from the island in the very near future, and it is vitally important that they are destroyed or captured before they can leave Sicily. This ensures that any subsequent invasion of the Italian mainland would be faced by far fewer Axis troops. 
The most immediate objectives are airfields and ports in the advance towards Messina.
Depending on his reinforcement schedule, the Axis player may attempt to delay Allies conquest of the island, or decisively defeat the Allies by a strong counterattack.

Game Components:
- Map Board
- Sheet of Counters
- Rules Handout
- One 6 sided die

Name: Sensuikan: Eastern Solomons Sept 1942
Description:
Japanese Submarine Offensive in the Eastern Solomons September 1942.

Sensuikan is a simple strategic simulation of the attempt of the Japanese Sixth Submarine Fleet to prey the U.S. carrier groups engaged, during the opening days of September 1942, in covering important convoys carrying reinforcements and supplies to Guadalcanal.

Sensuikan is a solitaire game in which a single Player controls both the opposing forces. The Player will command the Japanese submarine force by playing the role of Vice Adm. Komatsu Teruhisa , who, between August and September 1942, prepared and ordered the I-boats offensive from his headquarters in Truk. By contrast, the Allied escort groups will operate in accordance with a strictly defined set of rules. The specific game scenario will allow the Player to simulate the crucial moments which led on 15th September to sink the carrier U.S.S. Wasp and to hit some units of another carrier group built around the U.S.S. Hornet. As a consequence, the Player will be able to understand the logic of a submarine force whose potential was underestimated even by the High Japanese Command, and perceive the tension of Japanese sub-commanders in their ultimate search for high estimated preys, personal glory and, most of all, respect.
    Specific rules for random events, like intelligence resources or air raids, will add to the realism of the game. Concurrently, these elements will also offer the opportunity to examine through a different perspective, limits and contradictions to the Imperial Japanese Navy management of its ‘silent service’ during one of the most intense (and largely unknown) phases of submarine warfare of the entire War in the Pacific.

Name: The First Battle of Alamein: July 1st to 27th 1942
Description:
When speaking of ‘The battle of Alamein’ it is generally assumed that one is referring to the battle which finally saw Britain’s Eighth Army defeat Rommel’s much vaunted Panzerarmee Afrika in October/November 1942. However this was, in fact, the third battle fought at the Alamein position over a period of five months. The second battle, sometimes referred to as the ‘Battle of Alam Halfa’ or ‘Rommel’s last dash’, is seen as a necessary holding action which blunted the offensive capability of the Axis forces. The ‘First Battle of Alamein’ or ‘July Battles’ which concerns us presently has been given a comparatively negligent amount of historical attention; at times referenced as a hideously complex standstill or fatuously dismissed as insignificant. However, it was this battle which put a stop to Rommel’s gallop to Alexandria and began the change in Eighth Army’s fortunes that would eventually lead it to victory in November 1942.

The game map is a simple reproduction of the battle field of El Alamein in North Africa, from the Mediterranean Sea in the North to the impassable Qattara Depression in the South.

The Commonwealth player controls the units on the board which are Light Blue.
German Units are represented in Grey, and Italian units are represented in Green.

Name: Suomussalmi
Description:
Suomussalmi is probably the best known battle during the 1939-40 ‘Winter War’ between Finland and the USSR. It took place around the village of Suomussalmi and along the road leading to this village from the hamlet of Raate. The battle was fought between the 163rd and 44th divisions of the Red Army, the latter being a motorized division, against a composite Finnish division which was eventually called the 9th and had only a few artillery units and nothing else in support of its infantry battalions. The battle was fought from early December until early January and resulted in the complete destruction of the Soviet divisions.

The map covers the area around Suomussalmi and Haapavaara. It is divided into hexagons (hexes) each approximately 2.6 km across. 
The counters for the two armies are slightly different in the information they contain as well as in the color. Soviet units are red and Finnish units grey. The unit size designations and arm-of-service designations are the standard NATO designations with two possible exceptions. Two lines at the top of the unit marks a battalion and three a regiment.

Name: Another Glorious First of June? Jutland 1916
Description:
THE BATTLE OF JUTLAND - 31ST MAY 1916

The aim of this game is to create a playable, but accurate strategic simulation of the Battle of Jutland.  One of the most important aspects of war at sea is the difficulty of bringing an opponent to decisive battle, it took Nelson nearly two years to bring the French fleet to battle at Trafalgar, and in an era before radar or secure communication it remained as difficult.  Therefore this simulation uses a double blind system to simulate these difficulties.

GAME CONTENTS

2 Search Charts – One British, One German
1 Turn Chart
100 Counters:
- 64 Ship Counters
- 4 Fleet Counters
- 16 Contact Counters
- 6 Light Cruiser Search Counters (2 Red, 4 Black)
- 3 Engadine Float Plane Searches
- 2 Radio Intercept Counters
- 2 Submarine Contact Counters
- 1 Zeppelin Search Counter
- 1 Turn Counter

Name: 1st Manassas: 21st July 1861
Description:
This game simulates the battle of 1st Manassas 21st July 1861 at brigade level in a series of 30 minute game. One player represents the forces of the United States, the other Confederate forces.
The map board represents an area 8 miles wide x 7 miles long. Each Hex is 300 yards in diameter.
Units are represented by double-sided hexagonal counters. The simulation is at brigade level, but a number of un-brigaded units are represented as are artillery batteries.

Name: DGA TV
Description:
from the publisher:

A co-operative game about running your own TV station.

We are Producers working together to bring Award Winning programming to the viewing public. We run 7 Studios, featuring everything from Children’s Shows to Current Affairs. We have to deal with the critics, ratings, sponsors and the actions of people behind and in front of the cameras.

With skill and luck we will avoid Cancellations and earn Awards.

This game has the flavor of casino games such as Blackjack. We try to put together as popular a TV program as we can, i.e., as high scoring a card hand of the best crew, top ratings and committed sponsors to counter the negative hand of mounting drops in ratings, loss of viewers and sponsors as well as some troubles among the station crew.

Expect lots of talk and debate. Clever teamwork and risk-taking are also needed or we will lose our shirts as the Cancellations pile up. Be careful, everything can quickly spin out of control. Good luck!

Includes: 8 game boards, rules, 6 movers, 7 success markers, 1 program marker, 41 thumbs up and 45 thumbs down cards, rules summary chart. © 2006

Name: Austerlitz, 2 December 1805
Description:
This simulation deals with the famous Battle of Austerlitz held in Moravia (Chech Republic today) during the 2nd of December 1805.
The simulation is designed with a full area map (provided) of the actual place, divided in hexagons. The dimensions represented are approximately 8miles from north to south and 8miles from east to west, thus every hex represents an area of 1/16 of a square mile, the actual dimension of every hex is around 400 meters from side to side.
The player controlling the French army gets 33 unit markers all in divisional, brigade or battalion level.
The player controlling the Allied army gets 30 unit markers all in divisional, brigade or battalion level.

Name: 1847:  Road to Mexico City
Description:
This game is about the Veracruz Campaign during the Mexican-American War of 1845-1848.

The map is a 20x36 hexagon grid representing the operational area from Mexico City to the Gulf of Mexico and divided into three zones by red zone indicator lines. Each hex represents approximately 10km.
The Mexican forces are made up of primarily regulars of regimental size, but are augmented by Mexican cavalry, artillery, militia, guerrilla bands and local villagers capable of waging defensive combat.  The US forces are composed of regimental sized infantry, artillery and engineers.

Name: Dodge Bowl
Description:
Dodge Bowl is a novel dexterity game from Nash Games.  In this you set-up 5 'bowling' pins on your side of the board and 3 blocking cubes in the center of the board.  
     The object is to knock down your opponents pins first.  This is done by rolling a marble through a curved tube from your side of the board.  The rules are simple and the game is a fun way to pass the time.

Name: Globe Trotting
Description: Very similar to Twister but with an educational slant. A spinner is used and children must put left or right hand, or left or right foot on the continent or ocean specified. Last player standing is the winner.

Name: Personality Probe...?
Description:
It is a game designed for three or more players (special rules for two players) and the more the merrier.

There are topics for everyone: children, husbands & wives, general (for everyone), and master-mind (for the deep thinkers and serious minded.)  It is a good way to communicate with each other and learn how to think about oneself and life using over a thousand provocative, unique, stimulating and sometimes humorous questions.  Because these questions don't always come up in everyday conversations, it is a chance to gain insights about each other in a pleasant, relaxed, and enjoyable atmosphere.

Name: The Battle of the Nile
Description:
The Battle of the Nile - 1st and 2nd August, 1798
There are four different Scenarios that can be played, namely the Historical Scenario ( which simulates what actually happened in the Battle of the Nile ) and three other Scenarios called Scenario A, Scenario B and Scenario C.

The Board is a grid of flat up hexagonal zones, measuring 52 rows by 44 columns. The Board represents an area of approximately 2.5 miles by 1.9 miles at the North West part of Aboukir Bay.

Each counter represents one ship-of-the-line. There are 14 British ships and 13 French ships, each identified by their national flags and their names. Each ship counter spans two hexes.

Name: Westminster Abbey or Glorious Victory!
Description:
The Battle of Cape St Vincent,14th February 1797.
Each unit represents one ship of the line.  None of the frigates or other ships present are represented, as they played no part in the battle.
There are 15 British ships and 27 Spanish ships, identified by their national flags.

Name: Whigs & Scalps
Description:
Whigs & Scalps is a two-player grand strategic conflict simulation of the French & Indian War. The map represents an area stretching from the Gulf of Mexico to Northern Québec and from the Mississippi Valley to the Atlantic. The period covered goes from 1755 to 1760, each game turn representing a full year of real time.
Historically, despite some initial French victories, the British and Americans managed to conquer Nouvelle-France and effectively end French presence in Northern America.

Name: Clash of Empires: Magnesia 190BC
Description:
A Conflict Simulation of the Battle of Magnesia in 190BC between the armies of the Roman Republic and the Seleucid Empire.
The Clash of Empires game contains
- the game-map
- the Roman and Seleucid army counters
- “Push Back” counters
- A six sided dice is also needed.
The counters are organized into seven Divisions (four Roman and three Seleucid).

Name: Gladius et Sarissa:  Cynoscephalae, 197 BC
Description: This simulation covers the Battle of Cynoscephalae, a classic battle between the Roman manipular legion and a Hellenistic force descended from the army of Alexander the Great.  The battle was the result of heavy skirmishing and both sides quickly rushed reinforcements to the scene.  Therefore, at the beginning of the simulation there are no fixed positions except for your skirmishers.  Alternatively, you may wish to try your hand at the turning point of the battle and see if you repeat or change history.  Historically, the Romans won this battle after heavy fighting but can you recreate history or will you lead the forces of Philip V to victory over Rome?

Name: Wikinger Bande
Description:
Savana (in English language Savannah) is a fast, simple, family card game.
Each player is a Savannah animal. Each animal has its unique power. Each card represents one of the four animals in the game with a number value.
Every turn players discard two cards to form four piles (one per each animal) or they discard a card into a secret 5th pile.
When the secret pile contains 3 cards, these cards are revealed and put into the other four piles. The pile with the highest total value of cards grants his possessor 1 victory point.
The game ends when one of the player plays a special "end" card.

Name: Going Underground: Zoo Edition
Description:
Going Underground: Zoo Edition is the first game from Bright Sparx. It's played on a map of the London Underground and the idea is to catch animals that are on the loose. The counters representing the animals are spread across the board, face down. Each player gets the cards for five animals and the first to collect their set and get back to the zoo wins the game. There is an educational aspect as each card carries information about the animal depicted and the game is aimed at children and families.

Home Page: http://www.goingunderground.co.uk/

Name: Wall Street Junior
Description:
The game was developed with the aid of stock exchange brokers. The target audience are those people who want to have an easy introduction on the way the stock exchange works.

The aim of the game is to make your starting capital grow by buying stocks and gold. The worth of the stock fluctuates throughout the game, and the aim is to buy/sell stock at the most opportune time.

Winner is the player with the highest worth of stock and gold.

Name: Quick & Dirty
Description:
This game comes in 3 versions: "Für Frauen" (for women), "Für Männer" (For men)"Für Manager" (For Manager).

It is a mixture between "Bulls**t-Bingo" and "Once upon a time". One Player draws random cards with words on it, usually words coming from management areas ("Shareholder-value") and he has to put them into a speech.
Every time he says one keyword the other players can mark them on a "Bingo"-Board and they get points for - well for Bingo basically.

Name: Judkins shogi
Description: This modern variant of Shogi was designed by Paul Judkins of the UK sometime around 1998.  It is played on a 6x6 board and uses the king, rook, bishop, gold, silver, horse, and pawn from the standard Shogi game.  The promotion zone for each player consists of the final two ranks.  Drops are permitted.

Name: ATS: Tobruk Gamers Guide
Description:
From the publisher's site:

The Tobruk Gamers Guide covers Advanced Tobruk: Tank Battles in North Africa 1940-43, the monster-game that started it all. A move-by-move scenario replay, replete with analysis by the players, a detailed article on historical tactics -- worked up so it speaks 'ATS' system language -- and by an expert in desert warfare, and the first in a series of unpublished letter of Hal Hock in the 'Hock on Hock' series. And more, a LOT more!

Name: Warmachine Prime Remix
Description:
From the publisher's website:

Experience WARMACHINE like never before with brilliant new artwork, a Formula P3 painting guide, and new fiction about your favorite characters and factions.

With 256 pages of updated and consolidated rules, scenarios, errata, and clarifications; striking new photos and a full color map of Western Immoren; and an expanded, detailed glossary, it's never been easier nor more fun to Play Like You've Got a Pair!

WARMACHINE: Prime Remix is your single undisputed gaming resource for high octane metal-on-metal action. Prepare yourself, for victory favors the bold!

Name: Combat Commander: Battle Pack #1 – Paratroopers
Description:
Combat Commander: Battle Pack #1 – Paratroopers is the first of what will be many themed collections of scenarios for use with the Combat Commander: Europe series of games. The theme of this first Battle Pack is focused on the exploits of American, German and even Russian Airborne forces. CC–Paratroopers features eleven new scenarios printed on cardstock, as well as four new maps. Future Battle Packs will be similarly structured and may also include new counters or new cards – with themes such as “Stalingrad”, “Partisans” and “Desert Rats” to name just a few.

COMPONENTS:
2 17" x 22" 2-sided color mapsheets
6 2-sided Scenario Cards

The scenarios included in CC–Paratroopers are:

    “Fields of Fire” and “Fields of Blood” set at Lanzerath, Germany, 16 December 1944 – both the morning and the afternoon attacks (using a new map #25);
    “Turnbull Turns ‘em” at Neuville-au-Plain, France, 6 June 1944 (using a new map #26);
    “Carentan Causeway” at Carentan, France, 10 June 1944 (using a new map #27);
    “No Ingouf Around” at Carentan, France, 11 June 1944 (using a new map #28);
    “Operation Repulse” at Bastogne, Belgium, 27 December 1944;
    “Red Skies at Night” at Veliki Bukrin Bridgehead, Russia, 25 September 1943;
    “Blizzard Baptism” at Flamierge, Belgium, 4 January 1945;
    “Look Mom, No Tanks!” near Trois Ponts, Belgium, 24 December 1944;
    “We Go!” at St. Mere Eglise, France, 6 June 1944;
    “Encircled at Hill 30” at Caponnet, France, 8 June 1944.


NOTE: CC–Paratroopers is not a complete game and requires ownership of Combat Commander: Europe to play.

Scenario designs in this first Pack are courtesy of Will Green, John Holme, Gregory L. Wong, Bryan Collars, Ric Van Dyke, Tray Green and Dan Holte.

Name: Colpo grosso a Topolinia
Description:
This game was published in Italy in early '70.
Each player is a Disney character. Players are divided in 2 teams: "good guys" and "bad ones".
At the beginning "Bad ones" secretly choose a location where they will try a great robbery. "Good guys" try to find what is the target of the other team.
If "Bad ones" successfully rob their target, the player with the loot tries to reach one board edge to escape and win.

Name: Yamodo!
Description:
Read, Draw, Write... Pass it On!

A card is drawn from the stack and players must attempt to define the made-up word written at the top.  Each card also has a small drawing for players to add on to.  When you draw or get passed a card, you add to both the definition and the drawing, passing the card around until the word has been full defined by the players.

Name: What's Wild?!
Description:
What's Wild?! is a rummy-based card game for 2-7 players Ages 7 and up. Instead of cards featuring suits, the game's cards are made up of four different animal skins—alligator, cheetah, peacock, and zebra. And to further the "Wild" theme of the game, when a player's hand allows him or her to end a round of play, he or she must declare, "I'm going wild!"

A complete game of What's Wild?! includes 10 rounds. Each player receives three cards to begin the first round, and by the final round, each player is holding 12 cards in his or her hand. Players collect appropriately-named "herds" and "caravans"—called "books" and "runs" in traditional rummy games— throughout each round, until they are able to "Go Wild," or end the round.

Four cards - called "Chameleon Cards" change the Wild Card when played throughout the game. The four Chameleon Cards give the game a sort of "Old Maid" feel, in that if the card is in a player's hand when another player "Goes Wild," the player holding the Chameleon Card is awarded the maximum amount of points. In a game in which the low score wins, players must carefully weigh their options for playing Chameleon Cards when holding one. Playing the card too early may allow the Wild Card to be changed in later turns, but holding on to it too long may lead to an stampede of points. The Chameleon Card makes each round of every game of What's Wild?! new, exciting, and completely unpredictable.

Home Page: http://www.whatswildcardgame.com/

Name: Knights and Knaves
Description:
Subtitled: A Skirmish-Level Game of Combat in the Middle Ages.

Mainly for 25mm figures. 1 figure=1 man, 1 inch=6 feet, 1 turn=10-30 seconds. Typically, one player controls around 20 figures.  The rulebook comes with three sheets of Charts & Tables and a sheet of Organizational Chart (record sheet). 13 sample Organizations are listed.

Command Range (5 inches) is very important. In command figures choose Movement rate (full/half/no move). They are free to fire/melee. Out of command figures receive random Orders determined by rolls on a chart. Also, rules on morale, fatigue and ammo are included.

Later expanded by "More Knights and Knaves" (scenarios) and "Castles, Cogs & Chevauchees" (Siege, Ships and Campaign using maps).

All three now available free online.

    http://www.hisentco.com/

Name: OPORD
Description:
The game is on the market.  Anyone attenting RECON in Orlando is welcome to stop by the Flaming Monkey Games booth for a quick demo.  :)

OPORD is a game designed specifically to allow players to experience the sensation of launching a coordinated combined arms attack.  The game challenges a player with modern land warfare based upon existing tactical doctrine at the battalion level, but condensed in such a way as to make the make exiting and playable.  Players develop and execute operations to affect a coordinated tactical victory over their opponent.  To win, a player will have to successfully execute the instructions on his Mission Card while keeping the opponent from doing likewise.

In modern warfare, there is no shoot, maneuver sequence, as all shooting and maneuvering is simultaneous.  This is a key difference between modern warfare and that of WWII, and thus a main component of OPORD.  Movement is continuous, and shooting is sustained.  This is a key concept built into the OPORD game engine.  The variable turn sequence forces tactical forethought beyond the old “my turn, your turn” design mentality, and as a result players get a sense of fluidity of motion throughout the game.

Another key aspect of OPORD is the mission card driven objectives.  Players are not playing to slay each other’s armies, since this is akin to senseless banzai charges with no real aim other than to roll dice.  Rather, the game is set around typical “real world” sorts of missions that soldiers are given to accomplish.  Seize this hill, secure this route, recon in force here, set up a defense there—all of these are typical missions you’ll see in your mission cards.  And like the real world, you job is to use your troops and support elements to accomplish the mission.

In short, OPORD is a game that very closely relates the gaming experience to that of a real life Battalion Commander but in a fun way.  Receive your orders, allocate your troops and resources, design your plan, execute your plan, and complete the mission.

A typical turn.  Both players dice for initiative and turn sequence.  Initiative is obvious, winner goes first.  Sequencing dice determines the player's turn sequence.  Sequencing can be shoot/move/fight or move/shoot/fight.  the initiative winner goes first in the first two phases, while in the third phase "fight" all combat is simultaneous.  Movement variables are factored into the terrain boards, so there is no worry about modifiers for moving.  In combat, units shoot/fight collectively if in the same sector, or individually if in separate sectors.  Essentially both players dice (attack dice for phasing player, defend dice for non-phasing).  The interactive nature of every phase of every turn means no players are passive, which gives both a sense of fluidity.  Results are based upon combat dicing.  Units can be depleted, eliminated, or forced to withdraw.  The object of the game is to accomplish your mission and deny the enemy his.  While there are some mission cards that are all out attacks, most of the missions require you to combat in support of your own mission or to deny the other's.

Terrain boards are modular, so there is no limit to the size map one can create.  But a game comes with six maps.

Name: Princess Sleeping Beauty
Description:
In Princess Sleeping Beauty, the players portray princes hoping to awaken the sleeping princess.  In order to do so properly, a prince must have three roses when he's scaled the tower to kiss her.  The princes can collect a rose by rolling it on the die, or by picking one from the tower.

Ages 4-10

HABA game number 4494
Families: Folk Tales & Fairy Tales: Sleeping Beauty

Name: Caçada ao Tesouro
Description:
Caçada ao Tesouro is the Portuguese for Treasure Hunt. This is a game recommended for children Ages 5 and up.
Translated from the Box:
"Each step must be thought out very well. The one who capturea the hunters or deactivates the robots and finds the best treasures will be the champion of this Super-championship"

It is a chess variant with a child appealing theme pasted on. One player has control of eight pawns and the other of the two knights. The player with the pawns hides the treasures on the opposite side of the board, each treasure has a different point value. You play in two rounds,each player plays one time with the pawns and another with the knights. The players that when playing with the pawns gets the most points is the winner.

Name: Warhammer Armies: Army Books
Description:
DEPRICATED ENTRY

    
    
         This entry is outdated. It has been replaced with entries for the individual army books.

    


This entry is for all Warhammer Armies books.

The Warhammer Armies Army books contain the complete rules for playing various armies in Warhammer. They also contain in-depth painting guides, army lists, and much more.

Name: Triagonal
Description:
Winner of a Major FUN Award, and more recently a Dr Toy ~ Best Picks for 2008 Award...

Triagonal can be played and won in several ways...
 Win by forming a line of tiles or, by forming a large 3 x 3 x 3 Triangle of 9 tiles or, if the board goes through to completion, by winning the majority of board sectors ~ plus any Bonus points you may have earned during the game.

There are several other different games to play too, all of which can be played on our unique board including ~ one game which plays without the board at all.

When playing any of the 'Die Included' game option:
Players require some die throwing luck, but also, planning skills to place their won sector formers into the board to their best advantage and without leaving openings for opponents to gain from.

With skill and being observant, a player on their turn could win one or several sectors from their die roll.

Bonus Points:
Players can earn themselves 'Five' bonus points for Each (and every) Hexagon formed in their colour tiles.
Bonus points are added to the 'Final Tile Count' and could dramatically change the outcome of who actually wins the game.

What mood are you in today.?:
Choose a game option to suit your mood... Using None, One or Both custom die for different types of game.

There are Seven Game Options on the game box and 'More' additional FREE game options which can be downloaded from the publisher's website. 
Note: The additional game playing options were created after the game had been produced.

Game playing options include:
Pure Strategy, Chance, Quick, Solo, Team, Gambling (Fun or Real), Line Em Up 4 to 7, How Many (requires maths), Pass Over (no board), Exchange and more.

Include Exchange into your game and you could Turn Back Time by exchanging opponents tiles for your own, and maybe obtain that lost five point hexagon or even instantly win the game..!

Whichever option you choose to play:
Watch out for the Instant Win, Bonus Hexagon and Line Forming opportunities.

Triagonal can accommodate 1 to 4 players Ages 5 and up.

You can play Triagonal almost anywhere because game pieces are located and retained in the board during play but, are instantly cleared ready for the next challenging game.

All Triagonal components are injection molded:
Including the white triangular game board, 84 black Sector Formers, 120 Scoring Tiles (30 of each in red, yellow, blue and green). Also included are two custom 'printed' dice.

Home Page: http://sites.google.com/site/acumenboardgames2/home
 Note to all visitors:  
Acumen board games no longer exists as a business but, if you want to see more information Triagonal and other games stuff which are designed by myself (Dave Barnes), you can visit the following web address... https://sites.google.com/site/acumenboardgames2/home 
Hope to see you there.

See an advanced version called 'Supergrid'

Name: Day of the Rangers (Mogadishu 1993)
Description:
The Raid in Mogadishu on 3 October 1993 was the seventh in a series of raids mounted by US SOF (Special Operations Forces) Task Force Ranger (TFR). It was an attempt to immediately and dramatically seize the leadership of General Mohammad Farrah Aideed’s Habr Gidr, which was in conflict with UN forces being supported by the US. What was planned as a lightning raid soon escalated into a decisive, bitter and costly two-day battle. The aftermath led to the withdrawal of US and UN forces in Somalia and the consolidation of Aideed and Habr Gidr power. It was the most intense fighting the US military had seen since Vietnam. The course of the events has become familiar through the film based on Mark Bowden’s Black Hawk Down. For the Somalis the battle is remembered as “Malinki Ranger” which translates into English as “Day of the Ranger”. As has usually been the case Post Cold-War the fighting in Somalia was not about ideology but about Aideed and his Habr Gidr faction. In a war about an individual, seizure raids by SOF become strategic operations. Fittingly, it was also a conflict that pitted Aideed’s strategy of attrition against SOF tactics of raiding.

This is a very simple two player simulation of the October 3, 1993 firefight between Task Force Ranger and the Habr Gidr Clan in Mogadishu, Somalia. Each player controls either Task Force Ranger or the Habr Gidr Clan. The use of the title Day of the Rangers refers to the Somali name for the fight-’Malinki Ranger.’ The object of the game is to amass as many victory points as possible, the winner gains the most points, however the victory conditions set up to provide a balanced scenario outcome.

Game Files Direct Download: LINK

Name: When Hell Froze Over
Description:
"When Hell Froze Over" is an operational level wargame simulation of the Soviet counter-offensive around the city of Stalingrad in November 1942. Codenamed Operation Uranus, this offensive saw massive thrusts both to the North and South the city itself. Utilizing vast reserves of men and armor that the Germans where unaware of, these two thrusts penetrated deep behind Axis lines causing the German 6th Army to become pinched off, encircled and ultimately doomed. This simulation offers players two scenarios; Firstly the initial stages of Operation Uranus demonstrating the first chaotic days of the Soviet assault, Secondly there is a scenario simulating the ensuing efforts of the Germans to relieve the pocket whilst the Soviets strive to collapse it.

Game Components:

- Map board 
- Sheet of Counters 
- Game Markers
- Rules Booklet
- Scenario Leaflet
- Player Aid Sheet
- One 6 sided die

Name: BattleFront
Description:
BattleFront is a Cardgame for 2 players set during the WWII conflict.

The players fight for victory during battles on 5 different fronts:
- right
- right/center
- center
- left/center
- left
Win the first to achieve definitive victory on 3 of the 5 fronts.

Players draws their cards from a common card deck made of 70 cards.
The cards are divided into 7 categories, each of them is composed by 10 cards with a value from 1 to 10.
The 7 categories are:
-    Leader
-    Troops
-    Planes
-    Tanks
-    Ballistic
-    Strategy
-    Fortifications

Each turn consists of 3 different phases:
1.Logistic
2.Line Up
3.Battle

LOGISTIC
Each player draw 7 cards.

LINE UP
Place 1 card on the board. (one each player)

BATTLE
Sum the force (value on each cards) to decide who wins on different “fronts”.

The front is considered “secured” after 3 wins in a row.

Name: StarWars DogFight
Description:
StarWars DogFight is a cardgame/boardgame for 2 players.
As you can imagine by the name it’s set in the fantastic world created by George Lucas: StarWars.
The things you need to play is the dedicated deck available for free download (http://www.webalice.it/alecrespi/html/warpspawn.html) or in the files section, a little board (8x8) and a set of counters.

Each player starts with 8 ships.
The main objective is to kill 5 enemy ships (the remaining 3 will flee for fear).
    
REBELS starting units:
2  A-Wing (mov: 6, range: 3)
2  B-Wing (mov: 4, range: 4)
2  X-Wing (mov: 5, range: 4)
2  Y-Wing (mov: 4, range: 3)

IMPERIAL starting units:
6  TIE Fighter (mov: 5, range: 3)
2  TIE Interceptor (mov: 6, range: 4)

Players draws their cards from a common card deck.

The 3 main phases of the game are:
1- Plan
2- Movement
3- Fire

Name: Stellar Poker
Description:
Stellar Poker is a cardgame for 2+ players.
As you can imagine by the name, it’s a “variant” of the classic game named Poker so the only thing you need to play is the dedicated deck available for free download (http://www.webalice.it/alecrespi/html/warpspawn.html) or in the files section.
All the game is set in the space and the usual numeration of the traditional cards is replaced by the sequence of the planets in the solar system.

There are 13 different cards for each seed:
1    Sun        
2    Mercury     Internal Planet    
3    Venus    Internal Planet
4    Earth    Internal Planet
5    Moon    Internal Planet
6    Mars    Internal Planet
7    Asteroids    
8    Jupiter    External Planet
9    Saturn    External Planet
10    Uranus    External Planet
11    Neptune    External Planet    
12    Pluto    External Planet
13    Comets

Name: Jobber
Description:
The object of Jobber is to eliminate all of your own pieces. This can be accomplished by getting your pieces to their elimination corner or having your opponent jump your pieces Checkers style.
  The Jobber piece makes the game unique. The Jobber piece must stay in the Jobber row outlined by red squares and shaped like a plus sign in the middle of the board. You can use your Jobber piece to block your opponent's pieces or to advance your own pieces by having them jump over your jobber piece.

Name: Tee Off! Das Golf-Brettspiel
Description:
A golf simulation which includes all the elements of this sport: driving, pitching, putting, holes in one, water hazards, penalty shots, etc.

A full 18-hole course is featured on a beautiful huge board (98 x 68 cms).

Strategy and luck combine: players select a club (aggressive? conservative?) and then spin the distance disk to see how good their stroke was. The disk contains 26 different outcomes for each club.

Name: Federation Commander: Academy
Description:
Federation Commander: Academy is a lower-cost entry-level game for the Federation Commander Series. It includes the complete rulebook, counters, four ship cards, paper map, and a reference card.

Players will need dice and markers to play; everything else is included.

An expansion, Federation Commander: Graduation, allows owners of both Academy and Graduation to have everything in the base set: Federation Commander: Klingon Border.

Expanded by:

    Federation Commander: Graduation
    Federation Commander: Briefing #1

Name: O Guerreiro
Description:
The WARRIOR is wargame to combat foot in the pre-Renaissance period. Your system of simple game allows animated simulations and pleasure without sacrificing the realism or the coherence of the simulation unnecessarily. With him it is possible to simulate any combat foot of the pre-Renaissance period. Each scenario of the game (to be published) it will contains a brochure with your add rules supplementary.

O GUERREIRO é wargame de combate a pé no período pré-renascentista. Seu sistema de jogo simples permite encenações movimentadas e agrádaveis sem sacrificar desnacessáriamente o realismo ou a coerência da simulação. Com ele é possível encenar práticamente qualquer combate a pé do período pré-renascentista. Cada cenário do jogo (a ser lançado) contém um brochura com suas regras adcionais.

http://www.riachuelogames.com.br/guerreiro.htm

Name: Final Demand
Description:
Final Demand - The Disconnection Game

From the rulebook:

"Players race to connect their houses to the water, electricity and telephone supplies; then they try to remain connected, while disconnecting the other players.

The winner is the last player to retain all or some of his supplies.  Players who lose all of their supplies are out of the game!"

The game consists of a board, counters, cards, 30 coloured rings and 6 telephone poles.

Name: Dungeons and Patterns
Description:
This game was created by a couple of ubergeeks (of the software development variety) for other geeks. You can (as of this typing Feb 16 2007) read more about it at

http://oopsla.acm.org/OOPSLA02/ap/files/tut-32.html

Contents: one dice, two map sheets, a guide for the GM, and room descriptions/pictures for the players.

It's sort of a cross between zendo and a ridiculously light RPG. One person is the GM (or "Pattern Master") and describes what the other players in the room see. Everyone else in the room cooperates as the group explores a dungeon and earns keys by solving riddles together.

The riddles are usually of the form "You enter the next room and see these few objects." Players then suggest things to do to investigate the objects and their interactions. The GM tells them what happens as they explore. Eventualy the players regonize the software development pattern for which these objects are a metaphor.

The game was created for a conference attended by software developers and presumably has limited appeal outside that group, as few others would ever be able to identify the metaphor, having never read about software development patterns.

Name: Jewel of Truth
Description:
Jewel of Truth is a boardgame version of spin-the-bottle, designed for young girls.

From the manufacturer:

"Jewel of Truth will expose your innermost secrets and reveal your future! If the Jewel of Truth points to your colored jewel, you must reveal a secret, while other players try to
guess what you will say. When players match your answer, you both earn fortune cards."

There are five types of fortune cards; each player may hold no more than one of each type.  The first player to collect five fortune cards wins.

Name: Piratas del Caribe
Description:
Save yourself if you can! You will need all your ability and a little bit of luck to stay onboard the ship, when the wind makes your boat stagger and the waves cover it over. Roll the dice and try to maintain the load in perfect balance. If your pirate remains in the boat when all the others have fallen into the water, you are the winner.

Components:

     1 pirate ship
     18 pirates
     7 coins
     1 dice
     rulebook

Name: To Be Continued... by Gaslight
Description: To Be Continued by GASLIGHT is a game that pits steely-eyed, fling-jawed, barrel-chested, two-fisted, deadeye, tough as woodpecker lips, stud among studs, no kidding, stuff of legends, hero-type guys against colorful, charismatic, egomaniacal, dastardly, nefarious villains and their mindless minions.  Games, called episodes, are linked together to form twelve-episode serials in the tradition of the great movie serials of the 1930's and 1940's or the Pulp movies of the 1950's.

Name: Starship Troopers Evolution
Description:
From the publisher's site:

Starship Troopers Evolution
Based on the ever popular Heinlein novel and the highly successful film, this game uses the Evolution system to bring the War of the Species to your tabletop. Pre-painted Mobile Infantry, Arachnids, Skinnies and Forth miniatures will be appearing in the first wave of releases for this game, hitting your local stores in August.

From the publisher's monthly 'Signs & Portents' magazine:

Starship Troopers Evolution is based on the same game system as the original, though everything has been tightened, streamlined, and developed to give a far more tactical game.  The design of the best miniatures in the old range have been retained, the others improved and, to top it all off, everything will come pre-painted, saving you the trouble of creating forces from scratch, and allowing you to get straight into the game itself.

Replaced

    Starship Troopers Miniatures Game

Name: Peter Pan's Adventure Land Board Game
Description:
You will travel to Never Never Land and actually become Peter Pan or one of the other well-loved characters, and your aim is to become the first player to reach Captain Hook's Galleon - the Jolly Roger.

On your journey, you will encounter many obstacles: watch out for the Crocodile Square and avoid if you can the gushing mysterious river that could sweep you down the board. There are many pitfalls awaiting the unsuspecting player.

ages 3 & above
Families: Folk Tales & Fairy Tales: Peter Pan

Name: Paths and Burrows (The World of Beatrix Potter)
Description:
To move your rabbit playing piece from "start" to "home" over 49 steps, using the roll of the dice. You are helped on your way by taking short-cut paths if they are landed on, but you are also hindered if you land on a burrow, and you take a short-cut backwards!

The game is designed as if it was Beatrix Potter herself who had created it. All the parts and pieces used are made in materials that would have been available to her. The box is small and compact to take the well thought out pieces and is in keeping with the small book itself.

Snakes and Ladders is a Victorian game brought back from India and has the concept of good and bad, just right for Peter Rabbit. The illustrations used in the board design show Peter being naughty at one end of the burrow and then the result of being naughty at the other after he goes down. On the Path when he is good he goes up and the illustrations at either end depict this.

The game is very simple and can be played by three year old's upward. It should take no longer than five minutes to play, the concentration span of children of that age and perfect before bedtime. Hence the simple Paths and Burrows on the board and there being only 49 squares. If you want to spend longer then play more times, best of three etc.

The large wooden die has large numbers to help a child learn the numbers from 1 to 6. Each number is also decorated with the same number of rabbits. So there is one on the 1 and two on the 2 etc. Children will love counting these to see what number they have thrown. You can then move this number on the board. This will help them understand the relationship with the board numbers and the dice at an early age.

The pieces are Peter and the three Flopsy bunnies in stone resin and with painted jackets. They will bring Peter alive on the board to a young persons mind.

It is a gift item not a toy. By spending time with the game and taking care of it a child will come to appreciate it as they grow old. The textures and shapes and illustrations all blending to create an experience they will always remember.

Name: Minnesotaopoly
Description:
From the back of the box:

"To Play:  Buy campus properties and favorite area businesses as you make your way around the board.  Collect credit hours and trade them for diplomas.  Academic Probation sends you home...or make the Dean's list and collect a $200 scholarship."

This is a University of Minnesota Monopoly themed variant.

Name: The New Avengers Board Game
Description: The objective of the game is to be the first player to get their three Avenger figures into the Assignment Completed Area.

Name: PanzerTruppe: Armored Combat in World War II
Description:
From the author:
"PanzerTruppe is a set of tactical 1:1 rules for gaming WWII armored combat using 6mm micro armor and 10mm miniatures (1/300 through 1/200 scale). The basic rules comprise only a few pages of text. Optional rules are provided for advanced play involving infantry, anti-tank guns, artillery, mortars, air support, minefields, indirect fire, hedgerows, hidden set up, and more. Specifications are provided for more than 200 armored fighting vehicles covering all major nationalities from 1939 through 1945."
 From the rulebook:
Sequence of Play:
The game proceeds through the following 10 phases in order.
The phases are repeated

     Axis Morale & Load
     Axis Fire
     Axis Movement
     Allied Fire
     Axis Fire
     Allied Morale & Load
     Allied Fire
     Allied Movement
     Axis Fire
     Allied Fire


There are no "turns", the actions of the 2 sides are interleaved.

Name: Ben 10 Collectible Card Game
Description:
Battle your opponent by transforming in to your favorite alien from the Omnitrix! Attack your opponents forces on Earth or in space. Use a fireball from Heatblast or the strength of Fourarms to carry the day!

You start the game with 10,000 life points, and lose when your life points reach 0 on the play mat. Cards have a healthy and injured Battle rating, and aliens have a transformation time limit. Use an Effect card to cause your heroes to appear, or a Trick card to confuse your opponent. Your starting deck is 40 cards.

Name: Murder Mystery Party:  Murder by Magic
Description:
Solve a murder in an evening with friends.

Lord David Coppertone was hosting the annual convention of the Magic Ring in his new home Magic Mansion, which is being attended by the world's top magicians, conjurors, illusionists, escapologists and mystics.

Lord Coppertone performs his most dangerous of stunts to escape from the medieval Iron Maiden torture chamber. However, all did not go according to plan and Lord Coppertone fails to make the great escape.

Host your own party and discover who conjured up this cunning plan...or is it just an illusion!

The Game Pack includes all the material, information and suggestions for you to host this party...including costume suggestions, menu suggestions, invitations, name tags and clues.

Name: Battlestations: The Planet of Dr. Moreau
Description:
This expansion/mini-campaign lets the characters play two different sides. Players can choose to be "animal men" serving Dr. Moreau or play the U.R.E.F. exploring the strange happenings in this sector of space.

Expands:

    Battlestations

Name: Dragon Bones
Description:
From the publisher:

The time and place is Mongolia of the 1920s. Warlords and free-roaming bandits battle for control of the countryside. Your team of researchers and explorers must race against time to recover the fossils and get them out of the dangerous warzone and back to the safety of the International Zone in Shanghai.

The scenarios in Dragon Bones: Adventures in the Gobi Desert are designed for 2 to 6 players. There are four chapters (scenarios), each is capable of being played in a single evening or several can be played at one session.

This book also introduces nine new archetypes to .45 Adventure; including Professors, Bandits, and the Dragon Lady. There are new rules for Mounted models and eight new skills you can add to provide even more diversification for your figures.

So put on your campaign hat, strap on your .45 and get ready for Dragon Bones: Adventures in the Gobi Desert!

44 Pages

Name: The Gargoyle: Death Soldiers of the Jade Hood
Description:
From the Publisher:

The Gargoyle: Death Soldiers of the Jade Hood is the third supplement to the .45 Adventure rules and covers rules for campaigns and experience for your pulp heroes and villains.

This supplement explains how to set up your campaign, what you should do in advance, and even how to use minimal scenics to create a series of games.

It also provides new archetypes, new abilities, and expanded rules to allow more than just combat to occur in each game. There is also a nine-part campaign game where the outcome of each chapter effects what happens in the next one. Can the Gargoyle and his compatriots, along with the New Commerce police force, stop the Jade Hood and his mad plans to enslave the citizens of the city?

You will also get background material on the city of New Commerce to help you plan your own campaign in the home city of The Gargoyle and the Jade Hood!

Name: German Rails
Description:
This is a web-publsihed variant based on the well-known Empire Builder system by Mayfair Games.  True to its name, the game takes place on a map of Germany.  Of interest to gamers, one of the loads in this game is games. This was designed by the same designer of the similar game, African Rails.

The game can be downloaded at:
http://www.zahag.de/MMsKSg/rails/gr/main.html

Name: African Rails
Description: A web-published variant of the well-known Empire Builder system by Mayfair Games.  True to its name, this one takes place on the continent of Africa.  This was designed by the same designer of the similar game, German Rails.

Name: Inheritance
Description:
Requiring no prior bible knowledge, Inheritance teaches the Seven Pillars of Wisdom (Prov.9:1) while players have fun trading, hugging, paying tithes and making offerings for the poor. The winner ascending to the center of the inner board celebrates Christ as the Lamb of God in a final result where everyone wins as "Happy is the man who finds Wisdom." (Prov.3:13).  
 Designed for 3-7 players and ages from 8-to adult, game play in Inheritance offers a level of play which will be immediately familiar to both Monopoly and Parcheesi players, providing a completely new board game experience and principally cultivating the Wisdom of God.

Name: Het Grote Ronde van Vlaanderen Spel
Description:
A roll and move game about the most famous bicycle race in Flanders " The Tour of Flanders". Players have a choice of one of 3 standard dice (D4, D6, D8), or, if they have the proper cards, a D10, D12 or D16.

There are 3 levels of play, which can be mixed (1 and 3, or 1,2 and 3)) containing the more advanced rules adding strategic cards, which can influenec also other players changes, negative cards, and the peleton, which just like in the real cycle competition can influence the results of each player quite intensively and which for the more strategic gamers is the ultimate way to use them at their advantage.

Undoubtly real cycle geeks will have great fun playing the roles of their cycle hero's, but also the gamer can find his kicks in the game once all the levels are combined.

The game is available in 5 languages and can be ordered on:
Home Page: http://www.rondevanvlaanderenspel.com/ (English content is not yet available)

Name: Laerad
Description:
As written on the front cover: "Laerad is a strategic-level fantasy war game"

Up to seven fantasy armies struggle for supremacy on the world of Laerad.

The game requires 30 (!) 6-sided dice: 10 red, 10 white and 10 blue ones.

The armies are identical (yes, even dwarves and elves...), but an optional rule adds some racial differences.

Rules are in Italian and English.

Name: Wildcat Soccer
Description:
This is a card game for 2 players.  Available for free download or in the files section.

Players represent the coaches of different soccer teams, but not "professional teams".  You have to train and play with a team full of young and unexperienced players!

Play a game divided in 2 halves (like a real soccer game) and choose the right action in the right moment, because different players have different abilities (attack, defense, strength, etc.).

Who wins the match, wins the game.

Home Page: http://www.webalice.it/alecrespi/html/warpspawn.html

Name: BattleTech: Solaris VII – The Game World
Description:
From the back cover:

""Let the Games begin!"

The bay door swings up and away, revealing your opponent across a labyrinth of obstacles rising from the arena floor. Barely aware that the signal has been given, you are off and running, weapons blazing to cover your desperate sprint to safety. Diving through a maelstrom of explosions, you round a corner and charge your foe, ignoring the insistent flashing of your warning lights.

Welcome to the Game World, where war is a busines and life is a gamble.

Solaris VII is a supplemental for use with BattleTech and MechWarrior, providing everything needed for a MechWarrior to experience the life of a gladiator up close and personal. From the deadly 'Mech duels to the nightly intrigues at Thor's Shieldhall, Solaris VII challenges all the skills your characters possess.

Solaris VII includes a full-color map of Solaris City, a gazetteer of the Game World, a gamemaster's guide, and a full-color map for each of the 5 arenas run by the Great Houses of the Inner Sphere. Solaris VII also introduces the BattleMech Dueling System, a BattleTech expansion for running one-to-one tactical combat with more tactical options than ever before.

How good are you?

On Solaris, finding out will get you rich or get you killed."

User comment:

Solaris VII is a supplement for use with Battletech.  In addition to providing arena maps and scenarios, it introduces the "Battlemech Dueling System"

The Battlemech Dueling System is an expansion for running one-to-one compbat, with more tactical options than before.

Expands:

    BattleTech


The BattleMech's introduced in this box set weren't added to the mainstream BattleTech universe until FanPro released the Classic BattleTech: Technical Readout: 3055 Upgrade, 14 years after Solaris VII was first printed.

Name: The American Civil War by Gaslight, Part I:1861-63
Description:
A book of six American Civil War scenarios for use with the popular set of Victorian Science Fiction rules: GASLIGHT.

Contains Board setup, Victory conditions, and background information basd on an alternative history.

Expands:

    Gaslight

Name: Zombies!!! 6: Six Feet Under
Description:
You have always thought.. “There has got to be an easier way to get around town!” Well, now you found one... Or did you? There can’t be zombies underground, right?

Zombies!!! 6: 6 Feet Under adds a whole new “level” of  to the Zombies!!! series. With this expansion players are now free to explore the underground subways and sewers beneath the city.

This expansion could be played stand-alone with shotgun guys (or other player markers) and tokens for bullets and hearts.

Name: Captain Scarlet Game
Description:
Waddington's Captain Scarlet Game - The fight with the Mysterons.

Based on Gerry Anderson's TV series "Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons".
Licensed by Century 21 Merchandising Ltd.

Important people in Europe, as in the rest of the world, are under the constant threat of the Mysterons. A Conference has been called - to take place on the southern border of Yugoslavia - to which Heads of Government must be brought from four Regional Bases. Spectrum Patrol Cars, under the command of Captain Scarlet, Captain Blue, Captain Ochre and Lt. Green are assigned to this task.

After completing this assignment... the Conference decides to send new and detailed defence plans to places all over the Continent. It will require several separate journeys and each one must end at Durness, Scotland... where a plane waits to take information to Cloudbase.
It is the duty of Captain Scarlet and his colleagues to take a convoy along this route and get at least one Patrol Car through to Durness. The Mysterons, will of course, try to destroy the plans.

Name: Office Gossip
Description:
Office Gossip is game of scheming and intrigue set in an office environment for five to thirteen (or more) players. All players but one are dedicated office managers just doing their best to help the company. One player is a gossip who’s decided that the best way to get ahead is to eliminate competition by slandering the other managers. Will you figure out who the gossip is before you get demoted to “sanitation engineer”?

Office Gossip borrows almost all of the same play elements of the well-known public domain game Werewolf, also known as Mafia.  Where Werewolf requires a player to stay out of the game to act as a Narrator, Office Gossip uses a custom set of cards to eliminate the need for a Narrator.

Home Page: http://www.invisible-city.com/play/435/

Name: Amen! Game
Description: This game is a Bible trivia version of Bingo. But instead of the letters of "bingo" for the columns, the columns of this game are A, M, E, N and !. According to the rules of the game: the exclamation point column is to be identified as the "Halleluiah" column. Another difference is that the moderator does not simply call out squares to be covered on the player's card, but will indicate a column and read a question from one of five question cards. If you know the answer and have the answer on your card, then you cover that square. For instance, the moderator might say: "Column A. Who killed Goliath?" If you have David in your card's Column A, you would cover it. The free square is known in this game as "Free Salvation by Jesus." The first player to complete a horizontal, vertical or diagonal row calls out "Amen!" and wins the game.
